query: Stacy has $d$ dollars. She enters a mall with $10$ shops and a lottery stall. First she goes to the lottery and her money is doubled, then she goes into the first shop and spends $1024$ dollars. After that she alternates playing the lottery and getting her money doubled (Stacy always wins) then going into a new shop and spending $\$1024$. When she comes out of the last shop she has no money left. What is the minimum possible value of $d$?
ground_truth:
After the first lottery and first shop, Stacy has
\[2d - 1024\]dollars.  After the second lottery and second shop, Stacy has
\[2(2d - 1024) - 1024 = 2^2 d - (1 + 2) 1024\]dollars.  After the third lottery and third shop, Stacy has
\[2(2^2 d - (1 + 2) 1024) - 1024 = 2^3 d - (1 + 2 + 2^2) 1024\]dollars.

More generally, after the $n$th lottery and $n$th shop, Stacy has
\[2^n d - (1 + 2 + 2^2 + \dots + 2^{n - 1}) 1024 = 2^n d - 1024 (2^n - 1)\]dollars.  In particular, for $n = 10,$ Stacy has
\[1024d - 1024 (1023)\]dollars, which is also 0.  Hence, $d = \boxed{1023}.$

\[
2(2d - 1024) = 4d - 2048
\]
After this, she spends another \( 1024 \) dollars in the second shop, so her remaining money is:
\[
4d - 2048 - 1024 = 4d - 3072
\]

Stacy continues this pattern of doubling her remaining money and then spending \( 1024 \) dollars in each subsequent shop. We can summarize her situation after each visit to a shop:
